p: The definition of white adipose tissue (WAT) as an inert mass for energy storage is long gone; over the last two decades the adipose tissue has been recognized as a dynamic tissue and key player in the modulation of energy metabolism ( 1, 2). Adipokines such as leptin, adiponectin, and tumour necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) have a direct effect on energy homeostasis and modulation of low-grade inflammation ( 3). The intake of high fat diets has the potential to not only disturb normal adipokine secretion but also to remodel adipose tissue by increasing adipocyte size and/or number, contributing to the development of a pro-inflammatory microenvironment ( 4, 5). These perturbations have been positively associated with metabolic disorders such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), insulin resistance, and cardiovascular diseases ( 6, 7).
